Literature Review: The synaptonemal complex (SC) is a crucial protein structure that plays a pivotal role in meiosis, the specialized cell division process that produces haploid gametes. This literature review aims to explore the current understanding of the SC's structure, function, and its implications for human fertility.The SC is a highly conserved, zipper-like protein assembly that forms between homologous chromosomes during meiotic prophase I. Its primary function is to facilitate synapsis, recombination, and proper segregation of homologous chromosomes (Zickler and Kleckner, 2015). The mammalian SC comprises at least eight major proteins, most of which are characterized by coiled-coil domains that enable protein-protein interactions and self-assembly (Cahoon and Hawley, 2016).Recent structural studies have provided valuable insights into the molecular architecture of the SC. Electron microscopy and super-resolution microscopy techniques have revealed that the SC consists of lateral elements, a central element, and transverse filaments that connect the lateral elements to the central element (Schücker et al., 2015). The lateral elements, also known as axial elements before synapsis, are formed along the length of each homologous chromosome and serve as the foundation for SC assembly.The SYCP2 and SYCP3 proteins are major components of the lateral elements, while SYCP1 forms the transverse filaments (de Vries et al., 2005). The central element comprises several proteins, including SYCE1, SYCE2, SYCE3, and TEX12, which interact with the N-terminal domains of SYCP1 to stabilize the SC structure (Bolcun-Filas et al., 2009). Recent studies have also identified additional SC-associated proteins, such as HORMAD1 and HORMAD2, which play roles in synapsis progression and meiotic silencing of unsynapsed chromatin (Wojtasz et al., 2009).The assembly and disassembly of the SC are tightly regulated processes that are essential for proper meiotic progression. SC assembly begins in leptotene with the formation of axial elements, followed by the initiation of synapsis in zygotene, and complete synapsis in pachytene. The SC then disassembles during diplotene, allowing for the separation of homologous chromosomes (Cahoon and Hawley, 2016).The importance of the SC in meiosis and fertility has been underscored by numerous studies linking mutations in SC genes to various forms of infertility in both males and females. In males, mutations in SC genes have been associated with azoospermia, a condition characterized by the absence of sperm in the ejaculate. For example, mutations in SYCP3 have been identified in men with non-obstructive azoospermia (Miyamoto et al., 2003). Similarly, mutations in SYCE1 have been linked to human male infertility due to meiotic arrest (Maor-Sagie et al., 2015).In females, SC gene mutations have been implicated in primary ovarian insufficiency (POI) and recurrent pregnancy loss. A study by Caburet et al. (2014) identified homozygous mutations in SYCE1 in women with POI, highlighting the critical role of the SC in female fertility. Furthermore, mutations in SYCP3 have been associated with recurrent pregnancy loss, likely due to the production of aneuploid oocytes resulting from improper chromosome segregation (Bolor et al., 2009).Interestingly, recent research has revealed that certain SC gene mutations can act in a dominant-negative manner, where the heterozygous state is sufficient to cause pathogenicity. This phenomenon has been observed in cases of SYCP3 mutations, where heterozygous individuals exhibit fertility issues despite carrying one wild-type allele (Syrjänen et al., 2017). These findings suggest that even minor perturbations in SC protein function can have significant consequences for meiotic progression and fertility.The mechanisms by which SC mutations lead to infertility are diverse and depend on the specific protein affected. Some mutations may disrupt protein-protein interactions within the SC, compromising its structural integrity. Others may affect the timing or extent of SC assembly and disassembly, leading to aberrant synapsis or recombination. Additionally, mutations in SC proteins may interfere with their interactions with other meiotic proteins, such as those involved in DNA repair and recombination (Cahoon and Hawley, 2016).Recent advances in genome editing technologies, such as CRISPR-Cas9, have enabled the generation of more precise animal models to study the effects of SC mutations on meiosis and fertility. These models have provided valuable insights into the specific roles of individual SC proteins and the consequences of their dysfunction (Bolcun-Filas et al., 2018).In conclusion, the synaptonemal complex is a critical structure for meiotic chromosome dynamics and fertility. The intricate interplay between SC proteins and their precise assembly and disassembly are essential for proper chromosome synapsis, recombination, and segregation. Mutations in SC genes can lead to various forms of infertility in both males and females, highlighting the importance of this structure in reproductive health. Future research focusing on the molecular mechanisms of SC assembly and function, as well as the development of targeted therapies for SC-related infertility, will be crucial for advancing our understanding of meiosis and improving reproductive outcomes.
